author: By Liza Weisstuch
title: Does Building Better Jails Go Far Enough?
description: As New York looks to replace Rikers Island, some say a focus on more humane jail design is largely beside the point.
content: Darren Mack remembers August 1992. It was so hot that the metal walls of his jail cell on Rikers Island were “sweating.” Safety guards on windows blocked ventilation. An industrial fan on each tier of cellblocks was meant to cool the place, but they hardly worked, recalled Mr. Mack, who served 19 months on Rikers Island on a charge of accomplice to armed robbery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Benjamin Mueller
title: C.D.C. Chief Overrules Agency Panel and Recommends Pfizer-BioNTech Boosters for Workers at Risk
description: In a highly unusual decision, the C.D.C. director, Rochelle Walensky, reversed a move by agency advisers and endorsed additional doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for health care workers, teachers and other workers at risk.
content: The director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Friday overruled a recommendation by an agency advisory panel that had refused to endorse booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid vaccine for frontline workers. It was a highly unusual move for the director, Dr. Rochelle Walensky, but aligned C.D.C. policy with the Food and Drug Administration’s endorsements over her own agency’s advisers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Making the Jump From ‘Girlfriends’ to Spouses
description: Claire Conroy Brown and Karin Gist met on the set of the TV show “Girlfriends.” They remained good friends for several years, though neither couldn’t deny a certain chemistry.
content: Claire Conroy Brown and Karin Gist didn’t think they would become girlfriends in anything but the platonic sense when they met on the set of the TV show “Girlfriends” in 2003. Ms. Brown, then an assistant to the showrunner, and Ms. Gist, a first-time TV writer, were focused on establishing themselves in Hollywood. Both remember a certain chemistry, though.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: For India’s Military, a Juggling Act on Two Hostile Fronts
description: Tensions with China and Pakistan stretch a cash-starved military, while the fall of Afghanistan to the Taliban removes a potential ally.
content: CHANDIGARH, India — After the deadliest clashes in half a century with China, India’s military has taken emergency measures to reinforce a 500-mile stretch of the border high in the Himalayas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Can Macron Lead the European Union After Merkel Retires?
description: Emmanuel Macron, the French president, would love to fill the German chancellor’s shoes. But a Europe with no single, central figure may be more likely.
content: PARIS — After Germans vote on Sunday and a new government is formed, Chancellor Angela Merkel will leave office after 16 years as the dominant figure in European politics. It is the moment that Emmanuel Macron, the French president, has been waiting for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: venerate
description: This word has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Coral Davenport
title: Democrats Consider Adding Carbon Tax to Budget Bill
description: A tax on carbon dioxide pollution could be the single most effective policy to tackle climate change. It could also be politically explosive.
content: WASHINGTON — Opposition from a single moderate Democrat to corporate and income tax rate increases has revived efforts in the Senate to draft a tax on carbon dioxide pollution as a way to pay for the Democrats’ proposed $3.5 billion budget bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Daily Covid deaths rise to a new high in Russia, where vaccine hesitancy remains common.
description: The government’s numbers are widely regarded with suspicion, but Russian officials appear to be issuing more urgent warnings about the virus.
content: MOSCOW — Russia reported its worst-ever single-day Covid-19 death toll on Friday as coronavirus cases rise in some areas and vaccine hesitancy remains widespread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: At Art Basel, Everyone’s Playing It Safe
description: Dealers brought familiar works to the flagship Swiss fair, and the event’s organizers soothed nervous exhibitors with reassuring gestures.
content: BASEL, Switzerland — Psychologists call it the “mere exposure effect”: Humans like what they already know, whether people, places, products — or works of art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Benjamin Mueller
title: Federal Panel Recommends Booster Shots, Opening New Campaign Against the Virus
description: Scientific advisers to the C.D.C. endorsed additional doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for older Americans but not for health care workers, in a possible rift with regulators.
content: An influential scientific panel on Thursday opened a new front in the campaign against the coronavirus, recommending booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid vaccine for a wide range of Americans, including tens of millions of older people. But the experts declined to endorse additional doses for health care workers, teachers and others who might have higher exposure on the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Ocasio-Cortez apologizes for her ‘present’ vote on Iron Dome funding.
description: In a letter to constituents, the New York congresswoman suggested she had changed her “no” vote because she had been subjected to “hateful targeting” for opposing the aid.
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Democrat of New York and the highest-profile progressive in the House, apologized on Friday to her constituents for an abrupt decision to pull back her vote against providing $1 billion in new funding for Israel’s Iron Dome missile defense system, suggesting she had done so after being subjected to “hateful targeting” for opposing it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Penny Harrington, Who Broke a Blue Ceiling, Dies at 79
description: Overcoming bias, she became the first woman to head a major city police department in the nation, in Portland, Ore. But a rocky tenure led her to resign 17 months later.
content: Penny Harrington, who, after years of fighting gender discrimination in the Portland, Ore., Police Bureau, became its first female police chief — and the first woman to head a major city police department in the country — died on Sept. 15 at her home in Morro Bay, Calif. She was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: House approves measure to protect abortion rights amid threats from states and the courts.
description: The Women’s Health Protection Act is unlikely to advance in the Senate, but its passage reflected a sense of urgency by Democrats to maintain abortion access nationwide.
content: WASHINGTON — The House narrowly approved a measure on Friday intended to enact abortion rights into federal law, as Democrats sought to counter efforts at the state level to restrict abortions and growing hostility to abortion rights from the conservative-leaning Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Michael D. Shear
title: As Biden hails Pfizer boosters, the C.D.C. director defends her move to include frontline workers.
description: Remarks by President Biden and the C.D.C. director, Dr. Rochelle Walensky, came after Dr. Walensky overruled a recommendation by her agency’s panel of scientific advisers against booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid vaccine for frontline workers.
content: As President Biden cheered moves by federal regulators to allow for millions of Americans to get booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention defended her decision on Friday to recommend the shots for frontline workers, a highly unusual move because it overruled her agency’s scientific advisers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Dan Bilefsky and Katie Benner
title: U.S. Agrees to Release Huawei Executive in Case That Strained Ties With China
description: China reciprocated within hours, freeing two Canadians, a notable resolution in a relationship that has been spiraling downward.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department reached an agreement on Friday clearing the way for a senior executive of Huawei Technologies, the Chinese telecommunications giant, to return to China after admitting some wrongdoing in a sanctions violation case, removing one major irritant between the two superpowers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Answers to Your Questions About Covid Booster Shots
description: Government scientists have recommended a third dose of Covid-19 vaccine for a select group. Find out if you qualify.
content: This week, the Food and Drug Administration authorized Pfizer-BioNTech Covid vaccine booster shots for certain older Americans and those considered at high risk for complications from Covid-19. Here are answers to some of your questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: For the U.S. Ryder Cup Team, Motivation Burns Naturally
description: The captain Steve Stricker seems to be encouraging the players to find inspiration among themselves, and from the fact that the Europeans have won four of the past five meetings.
content: HAVEN, Wis. — Steve Stricker, the United States Ryder Cup captain, has not delivered a single rousing speech to his charges this week. He has also refrained from showing them motivational videos, which many of his predecessors liked to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik and Dan Levin
title: After weeks of planning, U.S. pharmacies and states are making Pfizer boosters available.
description: Tens of millions of Americans woke up eligible for booster shots.
content: On the heels of federal officials’ endorsement of booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine for many fully inoculated Americans, some states announced plans for getting even more shots in arms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: A Nervy Trip to Kabul: How Ukraine Negotiated With the Taliban and Rescued 96 Afghans
description: Few countries have been willing to fly rescue missions into Afghanistan since the Americans left. Ukraine is an exception. It says it has a different definition of danger.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Before departing for Afghanistan, an elite team of Ukrainian troops gathered in a circle outside the airport and passed around a bottle of whiskey, a ritual meant to calm the nerves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Keeping the Dance Fires Burning at the Joyce
description: The excellent Bharatanatyam troupe, Ragamala Dance Company, reopens the theater to live performance with “Fires of Varanasi.”
content: The Joyce Theater, open to audiences again, has been transformed. I don’t mean by the new seats, which look like brighter, cleaner versions of the frumpy old ones. I mean by the presence of Ragamala Dance Company, the Minneapolis-based troupe that is inaugurating the theater’s in-person fall season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Joseph Goldstein
title: New York Hospitals Face Possible Mass Firings as Workers Spurn Vaccines
description: With a Monday deadline looming, thousands of health care workers in the state are risking their jobs by not getting a coronavirus vaccine.
content: In Buffalo, the Erie County Medical Center plans to suspend elective in-patient surgeries and not take intensive-care patients from other hospitals because it may soon fire about 400 employees who have chosen not to get vaccinated against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: A Dangerous Scramble to Evacuate Afghan Nonprofit Workers
description: Women who steered programs to empower girls are fleeing the country. But unlike people who worked for the U.S. military, they have no clear path to the United States.
content: Roya was the face of the modern young Afghan woman. As leader of a girls’ club funded by the U.S. government, she gave her troops a script for their lives that their mothers could not pursue: They were just as powerful as boys in their ability to change their communities, she taught them. Working for another small nonprofit, she helped build connections between American and Afghan girls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Partners in Business and Adventure
description: Caroline Matthews and Connor McCarthy met during graduate school at Stanford, while both were on a Buddhist meditation retreat in the Himalayas.
content: When Caroline Matthews is asked where she first met Connor McCarthy, she says simply, “We met in graduate school.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Cliff Freeman, Adman Who Asked, ‘Where’s the Beef?,’ Dies at 80
description: His humorous touch was evident in commercials for Wendy’s, Little Caesars, Fox Sports and many other clients. “We have to win with wit,” he once said.
content: Cliff Freeman, the award-winning copywriter and creative director behind many witty television commercials, most memorably the one for Wendy’s in which a gravelly-voiced old woman shouts, “Where’s the beef?,” at the sight of a puny hamburger patty in an oversized bun, died on Sept. 5 at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan L. Ranney and Jeremy Samuel Faust
title: New Guidance on Booster Shots Gets Ahead of the Science
description: The responsibility for making decisions about getting boosters in some cases has shifted onto individuals and their doctors.
content: There’s finally a decision on which Americans should get booster shots against Covid-19. Unfortunately, some of the new federal recommendations go well beyond the data and foist the decision of appropriateness onto individuals and their doctors. And by expanding booster eligibility to a huge swath of the population, the Biden administration risks undermining confidence in vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Comedians Turn Their Attention to Abortion
description: Alison Leiby has an hourlong set looking at the experience of an unwanted pregnancy. She’s among a spate of female artists finding humor in the issue.
content: A stand-up show about abortion sounds like a bad idea. The comic Alison Leiby knows that. Just look at her title: “Oh God, an Hour About Abortion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: A W.H.O. panel recommends treating high-risk Covid patients with monoclonal antibodies.
description: The expensive treatment, developed by the U.S. drug maker Regeneron and the Swiss biotech company Roche, has garnered attention as backstop for those who shun vaccines.
content: A World Health Organization panel has endorsed the use of a monoclonal antibody treatment for Covid patients at the greatest risk of being hospitalized or those who are not producing antibodies to fight off the disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: A federal program aimed at halting evictions is showing signs of improvement.
description: The Treasury Department disbursed more than $2.3 billion in rental assistance in August, the most of any month since the cash was allocated by Congress.
content: The number of low-income renters at immediate risk of losing shelter remained relatively low in the month since the Supreme Court struck down a national eviction moratorium, as a troubled $46.5 billion federal rental aid program showed signs of kicking into high gear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
title: The Ecstasy of Scientific Discovery, and Its Agonizing Price
description: “When We Cease to Understand the World,” by Benjamín Labatut, considers the fine line between the brilliance and darkness of human advancement.
content: WHEN WE CEASE TO UNDERSTAND THE WORLDBy Benjamín LabatutTranslated by Adrian Nathan West
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Newell-Hanson and Angela Hau
title: In Brooklyn, a Couple With Opposing Tastes Strike a Balance
description: Following a period of editing and rediscovery, austerity and abundance — and a wide range of objets — live side by side in this Bedford-Stuyvesant apartment.
content: AS A CHILD in Virginia, Michael Brown collected birds’ nests, stamps and mounted beetles and butterflies. By the age of 10, he had graduated to Goofus glass vases — cold-painted trinkets produced in the early 20th century that were often given as fairground prizes — and old-fashioned spectacle frames he’d find at local flea markets. His first job, at 18, was dressing windows at the Richmond department store Thalhimers, and on the weekends he began collecting antique furniture and curiosities, a habit that continued into adulthood, as he worked as an interior stylist and retail art director, picking up treasures wherever he went: a 1920s lacquered gold Japanese screen from a stint living in Portland, Ore.; sun-bleached sea turtle shells from a vacation in Maine. By the time the 59-year-old found his current home in 2013, a 1,000-square-foot, one-bedroom rental on the top floor of a brownstone in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn, he needed a 20-foot truck to transport the goods he’d accumulated. “I wish I could be one of those people who could buy a thing, live with it, throw it out and move on,” he says. “But I can’t.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly Whiteside
title: Liberty Season Begins and Ends With Thrills
description: Sabrina Ionescu’s game-winner that opened the season had everyone thinking playoffs. Nothing from that point went as expected, including the team’s postseason run.
content: The dramatic ending of the Liberty’s first trip to the playoffs since 2017 evoked memories of the start of this season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hayley Krischer
title: The Highs and Lows of the ‘Cheer Mom’
description: As a sport grows more competitive and demanding, an archetype has emerged.
content: By mid-January of this year, Kristin Wheeler, a self-described “cheer mom,” was exhausted. She was spending most of her days in the cheer gym or in the car with her bottomless cup of coffee while her 14-year-old daughter, Abby, a high school varsity and All Star cheerleader, practiced for major competitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Ahead of German Election, Hundreds of Thousands Demand Climate Action
description: Protests took place worldwide, but those in Germany had heightened urgency amid calls for the next government to do something about climate change.
content: BERLIN — Hundreds of thousands of young people around the world on Friday returned to the streets in the first global climate protest since the coronavirus pandemic forced them into lockdowns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: ‘The View’ pulls two hosts mid-show after they test positive for the coronavirus.
description: Ana Navarro and Sunny Hostin, were directed to leave the set live on the air while Vice President Kamala Harris waited backstage for an in-person interview.
content: A dramatic scene played out on “The View” on Friday morning when two of the show’s hosts, Ana Navarro and Sunny Hostin, were directed to leave the set live on the air after both had apparently tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: A Hawaiian Wedding, Complete With Tractors and Cattle
description: Alexa Wilhelm and Ikaika Sarme, who met at a Halloween party five years ago, were married on a ranch on the Big Island.
content: A wedding in Hawaii usually conjures images of sandy white beaches and clear blue waters. But Alexa Wilhelm and Ikaika Sarme opted to marry at Kahua Ranch, a working cattle ranch on the Big Island, instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Ehrenreich
title: A Journey Along the River That Separates Russia From China
description: As he neared 80, the travel writer Colin Thubron took a trip along the 10th longest river in the world, chronicled in “The Amur River.”
content: THE AMUR RIVERBetween Russia and ChinaBy Colin Thubron
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Kaiser-Schatzlein
title: This Is How America’s Richest Families Stay That Way
description: The longer we fail to constrain inherited wealth, the sooner the dream of a democratic society dies.
content: Most people have probably never heard of a “stepped up basis,” but it might just be the most important tax loophole in America — one that billionaires use to pass vast sums of wealth down to their heirs by avoiding capital gains taxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: No, California Isn’t Doomed
description: With a budget surplus and plans for fixing its biggest problems, the Golden State is looking a bit more golden.
content: California has been struggling. It has stumbled through the Covid-19 pandemic and recession, afflicted by wildfires, an epidemic of homelessness and stratospheric housing prices. Last year it experienced its first population decline in records going back to 1900. Its latest mess was a costly and unsuccessful campaign to recall Gov. Gavin Newsom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Two hosts of ‘The View’ test positive for the virus minutes ahead of an interview with the vice president.
description: Ana Navarro and Sunny Hostin were abruptly pulled from the set on live television after testing positive before an in-studio interview with Vice President Kamala Harris.
content: Two co-hosts of “The View,” Ana Navarro and Sunny Hostin, were abruptly pulled from the set on live television on Friday morning after testing positive for the coronavirus, minutes ahead of a live in-studio interview with Vice President Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins and Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Rochester Officer Faces Discipline in Daniel Prude’s Death
description: The departmental charges are the first to be filed against any of the seven officers suspended in the case of Mr. Prude, a Black man who died after the police placed a mesh hood over his head and pinned him down.
content: Police officials in Rochester, N.Y., said on Thursday that they had filed departmental charges against an officer who took part in arresting Daniel Prude, a Black man who died in March 2020 after the police pinned him face down on the ground and put a mesh hood over his head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: After a Choreographer’s Suicide, Ballet Confronts Tough Questions
description: Liam Scarlett killed himself after he was accused of misconduct. Now the dance world is grappling with the aftermath.
content: MUNICH — The choreographer Liam Scarlett’s “With a Chance of Rain,” a lush, expansive ballet set to a melodic Rachmaninoff piano score, would hardly seem a risky piece of programming. But it was still notable when the Bayerisches Staatsballett performed it last weekend at the Cuvilliés Theater in Munich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: Europe Tightens Purse Strings to Try to Pressure Poland and Hungary
description: Frustrations over rule of law violations in the two countries have prompted the European Union to block payments in an effort to bolster legal action.
content: BRUSSELS — For the past few years, Hungary and Poland have repeatedly gone up against the long-established rules and values of the European Union, even though they are members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Senators say they pulled out of a Boston Globe conference to back a union.
description: Senators Edward J. Markey and Elizabeth Warren said they had declined to participate in solidarity with journalists who are in a contract dispute.
content: Senators Edward J. Markey and Elizabeth Warren, Democrats from Massachusetts, said Friday that they had backed out of a virtual conference hosted by The Boston Globe earlier in the week in solidarity with the journalists’ union there, which is in a yearslong dispute over a new labor contract.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Trump Had a Mob. He Also Had a Plan.
description: The storming of the Capitol closed the door on one era of American politics and opened the door to another.
content: You can understand a revolution as a time when the unthinkable becomes, suddenly, thinkable. It is a time when the rules that ordinarily govern political life lose their force and conflict takes the place of consensus, a time when the struggle for power is a struggle to define the political order itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: ‘I’m So Tired’: Readers Respond to Schools Reopening
description: Following a collection of vignettes from schools around the country, readers weighed in. Here is a selection of their comments.
content: Last week, we published a special feature on schools reopening around the country — and how students, teachers, administrators and parents are faring. Reader response, mostly from teachers and parents, was passionate and heartfelt. A selection is below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Remembering Richard Buckley
description: Mr. Buckley was a well known fashion journalist who, despite being married to Tom Ford, largely avoided being the story.
content: There’s a photograph in Tom Ford’s house in Beverly Hills, a Polaroid of him with his husband, Richard Buckley, who died last weekend at 72 after more than 30 years of health issues resulting from cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Controlling Britney Spears’ Reveals New Details of Her Life Under Conservatorship
description: A new documentary by The New York Times features interviews with key insiders and people with firsthand information about how the conservatorship controlled the pop star’s life.
content: Watch on Friday, Sept. 24, at 10 p.m. on FX or stream it on Hulu.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jen Psaki’s Turn at the Lectern and Richard Powers’s ‘Bewilderment’: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: A Wedding 18 Years in the Making for Colorado Governor
description: When Colorado Gov. Jared Polis and Marlon Reis met in 2003 neither imagined they would one day be married.
content: Gov. Jared Polis of Colorado gets one question a lot about his Sept. 15 wedding to Marlon Reis. “People say, ‘You know, it took you a while to get married,’” Mr. Polis, a Democrat, said. “But what’s important to remember is that Obergefell v. Hodges wasn’t until 2015. So we really only waited six years.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Man Convicted in Thefts of a van Gogh and a Hals From Dutch Museums
description: DNA evidence found at the two museums after the burglaries led investigators to the suspect, who has now been sentenced to eight years in prison by a Dutch court.
content: A three-judge panel in the Netherlands on Friday found a man guilty of stealing paintings by van Gogh and Frans Hals from museums in separate thefts and sentenced him to eight years in prison and a hefty fine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Pakistan Says U.N. Envoy of Old Afghan Government Should Vacate Seat
description: Stopping short of urging that a Taliban envoy to the U.N. be accepted, Pakistan’s foreign minister suggested that stability had improved in Taliban-ruled Afghanistan.
content: Pakistan’s foreign minister said Friday that the United Nations ambassador from Afghanistan’s toppled government had no standing and that its seat at the 193-member organization should remain vacant for now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: A Bond That Began With Football
description: Natalie Wengroff and Paul Wiley met during their first year of law school at Washington & Lee University.
content: When Natalie Wengroff and Paul Wiley met during their first year at Washington & Lee University’s law school, they found an easy conversation opener in the University of Michigan gear she regularly wore from her alma mater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Sophie Kasakove
title: When ‘It Could Never Possibly Happen Here’ Isn’t an Option
description: A mass shooting inside a suburban Memphis grocery store was called “the most horrific event that has occurred in Collierville history.” But it was one the town had prepared for.
content: COLLIERVILLE, Tenn. — A gunman opened fire in a suburban supermarket, and employees and customers immediately sought cover, barricading themselves in freezers and behind pallets of merchandise. Police officers swept in, employing lessons still fresh from training in June. Firefighters followed, shielding themselves in ballistic gear their department bought three years ago in anticipation of a moment like this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: For Food Deliverers, the Promise of Better Pay
description: The City Council passed a bill mandating minimum-pay standards for delivery workers, who were a lifeline for New Yorkers during the pandemic.
content: It’s Friday. We’ll look at steps New York City is taking to improve conditions for low-wage food deliverers, who became lifelines during the pandemic. We’ll also fly into the New York Public Library for a glimpse of holdings you can’t borrow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: The C.E.O. Other C.E.O.s Turn to for Advice
description: Rich Lesser, who has run Boston Consulting Group for eight years, is stepping down at a moment of enormous change.
content: When chief executives face thorny challenges that they feel their companies are unprepared to handle, they often turn to consulting firms. McKinsey and Bain & Company are among the best known, often drawing headlines for some of their more controversial work and prominent alumni. But just as influential in the business world, albeit with a lower profile, is Boston Consulting Group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meaghen Brown
title: Remote Work Gave Us a Life Together. Now What?
description: When a return to the office threatens a relationship.
content: Before the pandemic, I measured the distance between me and Matt in increments of travel. Fifteen hours by car from Ventura, Calif., to Santa Fe, N.M. If I flew, it was two hours in traffic to LAX, then a two-hour flight to Albuquerque and another hour on the shuttle bus to the adobe casita where he stayed up late with the porch light on, waiting for me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan
title: When a President Wrote for the Book Review
description: For the 125th anniversary of the Book Review, we revisit the time Teddy Roosevelt gushed on our front cover about a book he loved.
content: Past presidents and soon-to-be presidents have long written for the Book Review — Herbert Hoover, Bill Clinton, John F. Kennedy. The very first one to do so, though, was Theodore Roosevelt, on Oct. 13, 1918. It was clearly quite a coup for the Book Review, then just over two decades old, to persuade the former president to review “Jungle Peace,” a new volume from the explorer and naturalist William Beebe about the jungles of Guyana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Sauerbrey
title: Farewell, Angela Merkel. You Were Once the ‘Leader of the Free World.’
description: Germany is ready to move on from its iconic chancellor.
content: BERLIN — In central Berlin, a giant billboard shows a pair of hands, arranged in the shape of a diamond, in front of a female torso dressed in a green jacket. “Tschüss Mutti,” the billboard reads. “Bye, bye, Mommy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Javier C. Hernández
title: Who are the Canadians detained after Ms. Meng’s arrest?
description: For more than 1,000 days, two Canadian men held in China have been in separate prisons. They have been accused of espionage, without evidence, and forced to go months without visits from diplomats. They have waited as their cases meander through China’s opaque legal system, despite calls around the world for their release.
content: For more than 1,000 days, two Canadian men held in China have been in separate prisons. They have been accused of espionage, without evidence, and forced to go months without visits from diplomats. They have waited as their cases meander through China’s opaque legal system, despite calls around the world for their release.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: In Race for 5G, Alarm and Security Services Get Stuck in the Middle
description: Covid-19 shutdowns and chip shortages have made it more difficult to upgrade devices and meet a deadline set by AT&T.
content: Melissa Brinkman’s troubles are threatening to slow down AT&T’s multibillion-dollar rollout of ultrafast 5G wireless technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Vershbow
title: Let’s Ignore Each Other in the Same Room
description: Why parallel play is good for grown-ups, too.
content: “Want to read quietly next to each other in Riverside Park?” I texted a friend one Sunday afternoon in July. I was exhausted from staying out too late the night before and filled with the dread that clings to those final hours of the weekend — but I didn’t want to be alone. “Meet there at 1?” she wrote back and I packed my backpack, excited to spend another afternoon both alone and together with a friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How to Paint 50,000 Miles of Lines’
description: In this lesson, students will learn how all those lines get painted on roads, streets and crosswalks across America. Then, they will celebrate other overlooked work that makes our communities run.
content: This lesson is a part of our new Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times in general. Learn more and tell us what you think here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch Ben Platt Perform in ‘Dear Evan Hansen’
description: Stephen Chbosky, the director of the film adaptation of the Broadway musical, narrates a sequence with the song “Waving Through a Window.”
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague and Emily Cochrane
title: Ferries in Alaska. Rail in Oregon. States Dream Big on Infrastructure Funds.
description: The infrastructure bill could reshape priorities across the country, jump-starting critical projects that stalled over funding. These are some of the possibilities.
content: WASHINGTON — In the Pacific Northwest, the aging Interstate 5 bridge, a main artery between Oregon and Washington, is at risk of collapsing in a major earthquake. Across Appalachia, abandoned coal mines leaking toxic pollutants are a threat to public health. And along the Gulf Coast, states like Louisiana are forced to consider novel evacuation routes to ease traffic on inland highways that often become clogged before powerful hurricanes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: In Biden’s foreign policy, friends and foes see echoes of the Trump administration.
description: At the United Nations’ annual gathering of world leaders this week, President Biden and Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken spoke ambitiously about international cooperation and a new diplomatic approach for a post-Trump America.
content: At the United Nations’ annual gathering of world leaders this week, President Biden and Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken spoke ambitiously about international cooperation and a new diplomatic approach for a post-Trump America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Claire Moses
title: Germany After Angela Merkel
description: The chancellor’s long tenure is nearly over. Who’s next?
content: American voters tend to like change. It’s rare for either major political party to hold the White House for more than two straight terms, and the president’s party often struggles in midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Here Come the Crypto Rules
description: The urgency among regulators to rein in the crypto industry has generated a flurry of lobbying all over Washington.
content: Financial regulators are racing to regulate stablecoins. These digital currencies pegged to a stable asset like the dollar are used in crypto trading, banking and decentralized finance, addressing the problem of price volatility that plagues Bitcoin and others. Stablecoins have become an important bridge between digital currencies and the traditional financial system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: A Backpack That Asks: What Is a Backpack?
description: On the second day of Milan Fashion Week, a tongue-in-cheek collaboration between MM6 Maison Margiela and Eastpak.
content: Fashion Week is back in full force, and there’s a lot to see. Blink (or scroll too fast on Instagram) and you’ll miss the details: tiny bags, tall shoes, feathered hats, leather capes and diamond dog collars. So as part of a new series, Wow Moment, we’ll spotlight things we saw on the runways that delighted or mystified us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: Faith vs. a Full Week of Work
description: You shouldn’t have to forgo religious observance to do your job.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Mair
title: Ron DeSantis Was a Slam Dunk. Until He Wasn’t.
description: By following a G.O.P. base strategy on pandemic issues in a state hard hit by Covid, he may have left himself vulnerable.
content: Among the possible contenders for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination not named Donald Trump, one governor has captured more than his share of attention: Ron DeSantis of Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Ephrat Livni
title: China Cracks Down Harder on Cryptocurrency With New Ban
description: The clampdown comes as China’s central bank has been testing its own digital currency. The price of Bitcoin dropped on the news.
content: China intensified its crackdown on cryptocurrency on Friday, declaring all financial transactions involving cryptocurrencies illegal and issuing a nationwide ban on cryptocurrency mining, the power-hungry process in which vast computer networks compete for newly created crypto tokens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Who is Meng Wanzhou?
description: Here is what to know about the Chinese tech executive.
content: When Meng Wanzhou was arrested by the Canadian authorities in the Vancouver airport while changing flights December 2018, she suddenly became one of the world’s most famous detainees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Condemns Border Patrol Treatment of Haitian Migrants as Expulsions Continue
description: Several members of the administration said that an inquiry into what happened was still open and that officials would continue deporting migrants under a Trump-era public health rule.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden vowed on Friday that Border Patrol agents who rounded up Haitian migrants crossing the Rio Grande would “pay,” calling the scene at the southwestern border “horrible to see,” even as several members of his administration stressed that an investigation into what happened was still open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Reporting on the Issues That Set Our Brains on Fire
description: Michael Powell, a Times journalist, discusses his job writing about free speech, intellectual life and campus politics.
content: From the years of his youth when he worked as a New York City cabdriver, the Times reporter Michael Powell has retained a mastery at switching lanes. A reporter and columnist at several newspapers, he joined The Times in 2007 and has covered national political campaigns and reported for the Business desk. He wrote the Gotham column for the Metropolitan section and was the Sports of The Times columnist for six years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Members of Congress Urge Biden to Intervene at Rikers as de Blasio Plans Visit
description: In a letter to President Biden on Friday, several Democrats said New York City “cannot be trusted” to manage the jail complex, which has descended into chaos.
content: A group of congressional Democrats from New York called on President Biden on Friday to use federal resources to address the crisis at Rikers Island, expressing a lack of confidence in the city’s ability to restore order to the jail complex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: The Best One-Bowl Cookie Recipe You’ve Probably Never Heard Of
description: These old-fashioned butter cookies promise to become your new favorite.
content: Brown-edge cookies may not look like much — and their no-nonsense name certainly doesn’t do them any favors — but don’t let appearances fool you. In the great Venn diagram of cookies, this little wafer lies at the intersection of Christmas sugar cookie, vanilla wafer and French tuile. They are absurdly buttery, crisp at the edges, just barely chewy in the center, and they go with everything. It’s a bold statement, but as far as cookies go, these golden rounds are practically flawless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Iowa’s Grassley will seek an eighth term in the Senate.
description: The Republican senator, 88, is the former head of two high-profile Senate committees and will spare his party a bitter primary fight to succeed him.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the senior Republican in the Senate, announced on Friday on Twitter that he would seek an eighth term, relieving Republicans worried about a bitter primary fight that could put the seat at risk.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Humans May Have Left Footprints on Americas as Early as Last Ice Age
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 24, 2020.
content: “I think this is probably the biggest discovery about the peopling of America in a hundred years.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Why Sex-Positive Feminism Is Falling Out of Fashion
description: For some, a porn-soaked culture is oppressive, not liberating.
content: In her new book, “The Right to Sex: Feminism in the Twenty-First Century,” the philosopher Amia Srinivasan, who is quickly becoming one of the most high-profile feminist thinkers in the English-speaking world, describes teaching Oxford students about second-wave anti-porn activism. She assumes her students, for whom porn is ubiquitous, will “find the anti-porn position prudish and passé.” They do not. Rather, they’re in complete agreement with assertions that could come straight from Andrea Dworkin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy, Michael Wines and Nick Corasaniti
title: Republican Review of Arizona Vote Fails to Show Stolen Election
description: The criticized review showed much the same results as in November, with 99 more Biden votes and 261 fewer Trump ones.
content: PHOENIX — After months of delays and blistering criticism, a review of the 2020 election in Arizona’s largest county, ordered up and financed by Republicans, has failed to show that former President Donald J. Trump was cheated of victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What Is the Ultimate Pair of Forever Jeans?
description: A reader, tired of chasing the latest fad in denim, asks for guidance in finding jeans that will last a lifetime.
content: The fact is, we are living in the era of everything-goes jeans. They are skinny, wide, boyfriend, flared, distressed, stovepipe, acid-washed, upcycled, jegging. Whatever you want, there’s a jeans style for that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler, Eshe Nelson and Jenny Gross
title: In Britain, Rising Prices and Shortages Evoke 1970s-Style Jitters
description: The nation’s economy is very different from the bleak days of the 70s, but certain parallels are unnerving Britons and loom as a potential headache for Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
content: LONDON — Long lines at gas stations, rising fuel prices, empty shelves in supermarkets and worries about runaway inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: The Philharmonic Tries Out Another Temporary Home
description: After opening its season at Alice Tully Hall, the orchestra found more congenial surroundings at the Rose Theater.
content: Maybe it was the surge of adrenaline that the New York Philharmonic felt at finally returning to live concerts at Lincoln Center after a year and a half. Maybe sizing down symphonic power for a temporary venue — Alice Tully Hall, with just over a third of the seats of the orchestra’s usual theater across the street — was a work in progress on opening night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Janty Yates on Dressing the ‘House of Gucci’
description: The Oscar-winning British costume designer on delving into the archives and working with Lady Gaga for the hotly anticipated biopic.
content: In seasons past, Gucci held a runway show on the first day of Milan Fashion Week. This season, however, the new collection is scheduled to debut in Los Angeles on Nov. 3 — not long before the Thanksgiving weekend release in movie theaters of “House of Gucci,” a film based on the true story of the killing of the former chief of the Italian fashion house, Maurizio Gucci, by his ex-wife, Patrizia Reggiani.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Subtropical Storm Teresa Becomes the 19th Named Storm of the Season
description: A developing system forming off New England is expected to absorb Teresa, which is not expected to threaten land, forecasters said.
content: Subtropical Storm Teresa formed on Friday north of Bermuda, becoming the 19th named storm of the busy 2021 Atlantic hurricane season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: Finding Common Ground in the South, San Francisco and South India
description: Sree Arimilli and Sandheep Surendran lived nearby in San Francisco and shared striking similarities. But they didn’t come together until they called on astrological forces (and a dating app).
content: It was ultimately a dating app that introduced Sree Arimilli and Sandheep Surendran of San Francisco. But more traditional and spiritual elements, as well as a bit of self help, also played a part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: ‘The Most Beautiful Proposal’
description: Samir Doshi popped the question to Leslie Arffa after filling their home with wall-to-wall flowers and candles. He hid the living room and kitchen furniture in the bedroom.
content: When Leslie Arffa was asked what she thought were Samir Doshi’s best qualities, she cleared her throat, and hesitated with evident emotion. “He’s incredibly kind and thoughtful,” she said. “I never met anyone before that I never got tired of spending time with.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Marcos Alonso and the Genius of Thomas Tuchel
description: There is no such thing as a good or a bad player, only one in the right (or wrong) system.
content: Things got so bad, at one point, that even Marcos Alonso’s father was telling him to go. His fallout with his coach at Chelsea, Frank Lampard, had been spectacular and it had been total. Alonso had been substituted at halftime during a game at West Bromwich Albion, but instead of dutifully filing out to support his teammates, he had instead skulked off to wait on the team bus, stewing at the injustice of it all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Another Murder of a Woman in London Intensifies Calls for Safer Streets
description: The case of Sabina Nessa, 28, whose body was found in a London park, has renewed national outrage over violence against women in Britain. A suspect has been arrested on suspicion of murder.
content: LONDON — The name of the murdered young woman was slowly intoned by the crowd who gathered in the southeast London neighborhood on Friday evening: Sabina Nessa. Sabina Nessa. Sabina Nessa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: ‘Andy,’ Gus Van Sant’s Warhol Musical, Is a Surprise but Not a Miracle
description: The film director set himself a steep challenge in his debut stage work. At least for now, he hasn’t quite met it.
content: LISBON — Gus Van Sant is no stranger to experimental biopics: “Last Days,” his lyrical, nearly dialogue-free meditation on the end of Kurt Cobain’s life, shunned every convention of the genre. Yet “Andy,” his Andy Warhol-inspired stage debut, which had its world premiere at the Teatro Nacional D. Maria II in Lisbon this week, may be Van Sant’s oddest tribute to date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alwa Cooper
title: In Louisiana, a Haunting Landscape
description: In a break from portraiture, Dawoud Bey photographed plantations on the west bank of the Mississippi River, drawing a line between past and present.
content: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-seen work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at a photograph by Dawoud Bey, whose latest exhibition, “In This Here Place,” opened at Sean Kelly Gallery in New York on Sept. 10.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Fashion Is Not Only for the Young and Skinny
description: Consider Missoni, Tod’s and even Emporio Armani. Time for designers to get with the program.
content: MILAN — The news of Linda Evangelista’s cosmetic procedure trauma has been the talk not only of the internet, where the former supermodel’s Instagram post about what she said were the negative effects of a CoolSculpting treatment has sparked vociferous response, but also at the shows in Milan, where Ms. Evangelista once reigned and where her tale has passed from one socially distanced chair to another like a fashion horror story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: The Restaurant Host Is Suddenly at the Front of the Covid Wars
description: Forget the powerful maître d’ of old. Today’s hosts are mostly young, inexperienced women who have to enforce health rules and deal with the sometimes violent response.
content: Caroline Young was thrilled to be hired two years ago as a host at Café Poêtes in Houston. She was pursuing an undergraduate degree in hospitality, so she thought the experience in fine dining would be invaluable. She wanted to be the first person to greet arriving diners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naomi Shihab Nye
title: Word Up! Three Picture Books and a Graphic Novel Celebrate the Power and Joy of Language
description: “Thao,” “Otto: A Palindrama,” “My Monster Moofy” and “The Wordy Book” explore myriad worlds within words.
content: THAOWritten and illustrated by Thao Lam
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Darity Jr
title: Why Reparations Are Needed to Close the Racial Wealth Gap
description: The U.S. government’s debt to emancipated slaves and their descendants is more than 155 years overdue, an economist says.
content: The wealth gap between Black and white Americans is too enormous to be remedied through incremental programs. What’s needed are federal reparations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: This Might Be China’s ‘Babaru’ Moment
description: Evergrande may not be another Lehman, but so what?
content: OK, who ordered that? You’d think that between Covid-19, climate change and U.S. democracy under siege, we would already have enough crises on our plate. A potential Chinese financial meltdown is the last thing we need. Yet here we are.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Pennsylvania Prosecutor Charged in Rape at Woman’s Home, Police Say
description: Jeffrey L. Thomas, the district attorney in Somerset County, Pa., was charged with rape, indecent and simple assault, strangulation and criminal trespass.
content: An elected county prosecutor in Pennsylvania who was charged on Wednesday with rape in connection with an attack on a woman in her home left the residence only after she promised not to call the police, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Doris Diether, Guardian of Greenwich Village, Dies at 92
description: She challenged Robert Moses to preserve Washington Square Park and helped save Shakespeare in the Park. In the process, she became a zoning expert.
content: Doris Diether, a full-time public citizen who by sheer gumption became a self-taught guardian of Washington Square Park and a Greenwich Village preservationist, died on Sept. 16 in the Waverly Place apartment she had occupied since 1958. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Sherwood Boehlert, a G.O.P Moderate in the House, Dies at 84
description: A champion of environmentalism who chided climate-change skeptics, he was among the last of the relatively progressive Rockefeller Republicans.
content: Sherwood L. Boehlert, a 12-term moderate Republican congressman from upstate New York who bucked his party’s right-wing shift by standing firm as an environmentalist, died on Tuesday in a hospice care center in New Hartford, N.Y. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How Did Californians Spend Their Second Summer of the Pandemic?
description: Finding joy even in bleak moments.
content: This summer in California was not what we signed up for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: In the Lunchroom
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this photo — or tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Michael K. Williams Died of a Drug Overdose, Authorities Say
description: The actor known for “The Wire,” who was found dead in his apartment earlier this month, died of intoxication by a mixture of heroin, cocaine and fentanyl. He had been open about his struggle with addiction.
content: The death this month of Michael K. Williams, the Brooklyn actor most famous for his memorable portrayal of a gay stickup man in “The Wire,” was caused by an accidental drug overdose involving fentanyl, New York City’s medical examiner said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Detains Business Chiefs as Its Corporate Crusade Expands
description: The seizure of the top two leaders of HNA Group comes as speculation swirls over whether Beijing will bail out another troubled giant, Evergrande.
content: BEIJING — China has kicked up its campaign to tame its free-spending, debt-laden companies, as the authorities punished the corporate chiefs of two troubled companies while letting a troubled property giant continue to struggle under the weight of more than $300 billion in debt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Booster shots in the U.S.
content: A U.S. government advisory panel has recommended booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid vaccine for adults over 65, for people ages 18 to 64 with underlying conditions and for residents of long-term-care homes, but it declined to endorse additional doses for workers who might have higher exposure on the job.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Weeknight Greatest Hits
description: We’ve collected some of our best quick recipes in our new special section. We hope you love them as much as we do.
content: Here at Five Weeknight Dishes we are always striving to give you delicious and interesting ideas for dinner that won’t take too much time to make — time you may hardly have in the first place. (You’re busy!) I’m talking about the recipes with the brilliant twist, the sharp shortcut, the technique that elevates something from just OK to truly good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: A Push for Social Security to Resume Mailing Annual Updates
description: The government has been urging people to create online accounts. But most haven’t, which means they can’t regularly check for errors.
content: With so much financial information available online, who needs paperwork cluttering your desk? But some members of Congress want Americans to get at least one financial document on paper: their annual Social Security statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: U.S. schools with mask requirements are seeing fewer outbreaks, the C.D.C. finds.
description: Arizona schools that did not require masks had 3.5 times as many outbreaks as those that mandated them.
content: School mask mandates have generated controversy in many parts of the country. Now, two studies, published on Friday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, provide additional evidence that masks protect children from the coronavirus, even when community rates are high and the contagious Delta variant is circulating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Burstein
title: What Happens Inside a Broadway Theater Can Help Us Heal
description: It is church for the heart and mind. It is shul for the intellect. A mosque celebrating mankind.
content: For 18 months, theater all but disappeared in New York City. For those of us who work on and around stages, our lifeblood came to a full stop. The theater district was a ghost town. My wife, Rebecca Luker, and I made our living on Broadway from a combined 27 shows in 30 years. We knew how lucky we were and pinched ourselves daily. And then suddenly it all ended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Benjamin Mueller
title: Biden Promised to Follow the Science. But Sometimes, He Gets Ahead of the Experts.
description: White House officials dismiss criticism that President Biden’s comments on booster shots amount to undue pressure on public health experts.
content: WASHINGTON — As he announced on Friday that booster shots would be available to some Americans, President Biden made a prediction: His administration was likely to soon provide third doses of the vaccine “across the board” to anyone who wanted one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Voting rights groups sue Ohio over a Republican-controlled revision of state voting districts.
description: “Ohio may be the canary in the coal mine from what we can expect from a partisan-dominated map-drawing process,” an official with the A.C.L.U. said.
content: The American Civil Liberties Union and other voter rights groups filed a lawsuit on Thursday challenging the newly drawn state legislative districts enacted last week by a Republican-dominated commission in Ohio, an opening salvo in what is likely to be a series of confrontations across the country as the once-in-a-decade redistricting process unfolds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Isabelia Herrera and Giovanni Russonello
title: Alessia Cara’s Bouncy Ode to Single Life, and 12 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Coldplay and BTS, J. Cole, Arturo O’Farrill and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder, Emma Bubola and Gaia Pianigiani
title: Italy Frees Catalan Separatist Leader From Jail. Here’s How the Case Has Gone.
description: Carles Puigdemont, a former leader of Catalonia, faces trial in Spain and was detained briefly in Italy. It is not clear if he will appear when the court considers whether to return him to Spain.
content: An Italian court released a former leader of Spain’s Catalonia region from jail on Friday, a day after his arrest on a warrant seeking his return to Spain for trial over a failed independence bid he led four years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: What’s Not to Like?
description: Stella Zawistowski opens our solving weekend.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Over my years of solving puzzles, I’ve done my fair share of nine-stack themeless grids such as this one. The joy of them is seeing what the constructor has placed in the stack for me as a solver to figure out. Getting a few letters, staring at the clue, “hit from behind,” with the letters R__RE__E_ and thinking, What could this be? That’s the fun of it for me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Lara Jakes
title: The C.I.A. recalls its station chief to Vienna amid criticism of his handling of mysterious illnesses.
description: Frustration is growing about the treatment of an increasing number of intelligence officers and diplomats with symptoms of so-called Havana syndrome.
content: The C.I.A. recalled its Vienna chief of station this month, after agency leaders concluded he failed to take adequate steps to address a series of mysterious health episodes in Austria in which intelligence officers and diplomats fell ill with symptoms similar to Havana syndrome, according to current and former officials who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss personnel movements. The names of agency station chiefs are highly classified.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darryn King
title: Mike Flanagan Explores His Private Horrors in ‘Midnight Mass’
description: In the new Netflix series, the acclaimed adapter of works by Shirley Jackson and Stephen King tells a more personal story.
content: The writer-director Mike Flanagan has become best known for his adaptations of works by Shirley Jackson (“The Haunting of Hill House”), Henry James (“The Haunting of Bly Manor”) and Stephen King (“Gerald’s Game,” “Doctor Sleep”). The horrors in his latest project, “Midnight Mass,” a seven-episode limited series that premiered Friday on Netflix, are homegrown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Emily Cochrane
title: How Democrats Could Shrink Their $3.5 Trillion Budget Bill
description: Here are three options to shrink down the Democrats’ climate change and social welfare bill as moderates demand less spending and smaller tax hikes to pay for it.
content: WASHINGTON — As Democratic leaders struggle to unite their caucus behind a sprawling domestic policy package, it is increasingly clear the $3.5 trillion in spending and tax increases will have to be pared back, possibly by a lot, to make it to President Biden’s desk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Texas, under pressure from Trump, announces a ‘full forensic audit’ of the 2020 election in four counties.
description: The announcement came hours after the former president publicly pushed for an audit of the election results in Texas.
content: Eight and a half hours after former President Donald J. Trump made a public demand for Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas to back legislation to create a “forensic audit of the 2020 election,” the Texas secretary of state’s office announced a “comprehensive forensic audit” of the results from four of the state’s largest counties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Why Is Rikers Island Still Open?
description: A spate of deaths and a mounting culture of violence at New York City’s largest jail renew calls for an emergency solution.
content: During the past few months, Rikers Island has been the site of sequential atrocities so stark that this week four members of New York’s congressional delegation called for its immediate closure. Among the most recent was the death, a few weeks ago, of 24-year old Esias “Izzy” Johnson, who had spent the previous month trying and failing to be released on bail and his final hours, his family claims, screaming for medical help in vain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Boosters begin, and how to persuade the vaccine hesitant.
content: President Biden said today that coronavirus booster shots for certain categories of people who received the Pfizer vaccine will begin immediately. He urged those eligible to get one quickly to fortify their protection from the dangerous Delta variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: The Future Is Knocking on Australia’s Door
description: With Covid, global security and climate change, the status quo has started to shift.
content: When I sat down to write my essay about Australia’s bifurcated approach to containing the Delta variant, I knew there would be scenes and insightful conversations that never made it into the article. I’d spoken to dozens of Australians across the country, seeking a mix of nuance and contemplation, and there are always moments you wish could be included. But one discussion came back to me this morning because it seemed to cover a range of the issues that Australia now finds itself confronting on the world stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: PG&E Faces Criminal Charges Over Fatal 2020 Wildfire in California
description: Charges including manslaughter arise from a blaze that killed four last year. A state inquiry said the utility’s power lines were involved.
content: Prosecutors in Northern California filed criminal charges against Pacific Gas & Electric on Friday in connection with the deaths of four people last year in a wildfire that was linked to the utility’s equipment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: Saving the Artwork of the South: Deep Investment, and a Drone
description: From Birmingham to Gee’s Bend, the Souls Grown Deep Foundation is directly investing in Alabama communities where artists and quilters live, work — and struggle.
content: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — “I’m the conjurer of all my ancestors, 400 years of African people in America,” said Joe Minter, surveying the dense outdoor environment of artworks he has forged from refuse over the past 32 years across his half-acre yard, facing two of the largest African-American cemeteries in the south. Nodding to the tombstones, he added, “they have given me the privilege of being their spokesman.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allie Conti
title: How an Olympic Skateboarder Spends Her Sundays
description: With the Tokyo Games behind her, Alexis Sablone is enjoying Brooklyn — and street skating — again.
content: Alexis Sablone doesn’t really have weekends. “It’s never like, ‘Oh, I’ve got to get back to work tomorrow,’” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Democrats Face Tough Choices as They Look to Shrink Safety Net Bill
description: With moderates insisting that the cost of the measure dip below $3.5 trillion, Democrats have a number of options for scaling back their plan. None of them are easy.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats are facing agonizing choices over what to keep and what to drop from their expansive $3.5 trillion social safety net package, as they labor to pacify the most conservative lawmakers in their ranks who have balked at its cost and scope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shelley Ross
title: Chris Cuomo Sexually Harassed Me. I Hope He’ll Use His Power to Make Change.
description: His former boss wants harassers and enablers held accountable.
content: I was Chris Cuomo’s boss at ABC News nearly two decades ago, and I am a regular viewer of CNN today, so I’ve long watched how he communicates on camera and witnessed at times how he behaved behind the scenes. This year, as he escaped accountability for advising former Gov. Andrew Cuomo during his sexual harassment scandal, two moments crystallized for me how Mr. Cuomo performs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Schwartz
title: That Comment Someone Left on Facebook? It Can Get You Sued.
description: Australia’s top court has said media companies can be held liable for replies to their posts, prompting some to step back from the platform.
content: Dylan Voller was already a polarizing figure in Australia when the disturbing, violent and demonstrably false accusations against him began to appear on Facebook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: The Cost of Insuring Expensive Waterfront Homes Is About to Skyrocket
description: New federal flood insurance rates that better reflect the real risks of climate change are coming. For some, premiums will rise sharply.
content: Florida’s version of the American dream, which holds that even people of relatively modest means can aspire to live near the water, depends on a few crucial components: sugar white beaches, soft ocean breezes and federal flood insurance that is heavily subsidized.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Some People Stay Behind in a Wildfire
description: And why we decided to cover their choices.
content: This week on The Daily, Annie Correal, a staff reporter for The Times, introduced us to some members of her family who had made a difficult and controversial choice. Despite mandatory evacuation orders in parts of California that were threatened by a huge wildfire this summer, they chose to stay behind and try to fight the blaze. Many of you wrote in with thoughts about the episode, and with questions for Annie. Here are some of her answers, which have been edited and condensed for clarity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Moity
title: Twin ‘Love Lamps’ Kept Them Close Even When They Weren’t
description: Raquel Begleiter and David Godow talked about the Byzantine Empire when they met in Washington in 2015. Their relationship became “a long-distance Odyssey.”
content: On an early September afternoon in 2015, Raquel Begleiter and David Godow met while eating pizza at a mutual friend’s place in Washington. Initially, Ms. Begleiter’s focus was on her best friend, Rachel, who was about to move to San Francisco. But then the Byzantine Empire came into the conversation, a topic of particular interest to Ms. Begleiter, and she and Mr. Godow began, in his words, “nerding out” over medieval history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Orr
title: ‘Ted Lasso’ Recap, Season 2, Episode 10: The Naked and the Dead
description: This week brings Ted’s origin story, and other tales of the damage fathers can do.
content: We now return to our regularly scheduled programming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: He Taught Ancient Texts at Oxford. Now He Is Accused of Stealing Some.
description: Hobby Lobby, the craft chain that helped build a collection for the Museum of the Bible, has sued a former Oxford lecturer, asserting he sold it stolen artifacts.
content: He had impeccable credentials. No one disputes that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Stream These Five International Films Now
description: This month’s picks include a slow-burn Romanian drama, a documentary about baseball in Japan, an experimental Chilean film-memoir and more.
content: Following an intelligence officer whose son goes missing on a blizzard-stricken mountain, this slow-burning Romanian film deepens familiar Hollywood templates — a father’s relentless quest to save his child; a battle of man against nature — into a complex ethical drama about the blurred lines between desperation and hubris. When Mircea Jianu (Adrian Titieni) first learns of his son’s disappearance, his reactions are what one would expect from any parent in his shoes: panic, despair, anger. He insists on following the rescue team up the slopes, despite the inclement weather, and lashes out at their seeming slowness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: Education Doesn’t Inoculate Us from Vaccine Hesitancy
description: What we learn is filtered through our identities.
content: I got in a bit of a dust-up online recently for concluding that vaccine hesitance and resistance to masking were not uncommon among health care workers — and that it wasn’t surprising. I based my conclusion on vaccine hesitancy on some personal experience — a nurse at my vaccine site was very vocal about refusing the vaccine — and on various surveys showing that not all health care workers are willing to get vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: Jared Harris Is (and Isn’t) His Father’s Son
description: The actor has emerged from the shadow of his father, Richard Harris, with memorable performances in series like “Mad Men” and “Chernobyl.” Next up is the sci-fi epic “Foundation.”
content: Ask David S. Goyer, the creator of “Foundation,” why Jared Harris was his first choice to star in this ambitious new Apple TV+ series, and he will point to one small, meaningful moment during filming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Amber Tamblyn Goes Dancing With Bowling Shoes
description: The star of “Y: The Last Man” hits Brooklyn Bowl for a girls’ night out.
content: Amber Tamblyn strode confidently toward the foul line and unleashed a sparkly pink bowling ball toward the waiting pins. Almost immediately, the ball plopped into the right gutter. Another ball, another assured approach. That ball guttered, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Review: The Math of ‘Foundation’ Doesn’t Add Up
description: An ambitious reimagining of the Isaac Asimov epic suffers from by-the-numbers sci-fi plotting.
content: The science-fiction author Arthur C. Clarke once decreed that any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic. At the core of “Foundation,” the Apple TV+ series based on the novels of Isaac Asimov, is a similar idea: that any sufficiently advanced math is indistinguishable from prophecy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
title: ‘Stop the Steal’ Movement Races Forward, Ignoring Arizona Humiliation
description: As a Republican review of 2020 votes in Arizona sputtered to a close, Donald Trump and his allies signaled that their attack on the election, and their drive to reshape future elections, were far from over.
content: After all the scurrying, searching, sifting, speculating, hand-counting and bamboo-hunting had ended, Republicans’ post-mortem review of election results in Arizona’s largest county wound up only adding to President Biden’s margin of victory there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: Black-Tie Season Returns
description: Benefits were held for the Public Theater, the Museum at F.I.T. and the Central Park Conservancy.
content: The Public Theater held its annual gala in Central Park on Sept. 20. The gala celebrated the final performance of “Merry Wives” at the Delacorte Theater, and what would have been the 100th birthday of its founder, Joe Papp. The Museum at F.I.T. raised $700,000 at its couture council luncheon honoring Wes Gordon at Cipriani South Street on Sept. 22.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Healy
title: Chris Cuomo, Andrew Cuomo and the Need for Accountability
description: “I see another way forward.”
content: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Charles G. Sellers, Historian Who Upset the Postwar Consensus, Dies at 98
description: A Southerner who became a radical at Berkeley, he argued that democracy developed in America as a response to the emergence of industrial capitalism.
content: Charles G. Sellers, a historian whose work on early-19th-century America helped overturn the postwar consensus that democracy and capitalism developed in tandem by showing that in fact they were more often at odds, died on Thursday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Could This Covid Wave Reverse the Recovery? Here’s What to Watch.
description: Some businesses are still hurting, and federal aid has wound down. But economists see sources of resilience and signs of strength.
content: The spread of the Delta variant has delayed office reopenings, disrupted the start of school and generally dashed hopes for a return to normal after Labor Day. But it has not pushed the U.S. economic recovery into reverse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Luke Vander Ploeg, Kaitlin Roberts, Daniel Guillemette, Stella Tan, Alexandra Leigh Young, Michael Simon Johnson, Clare Toeniskoetter, Anita Badejo, Chelsea Daniel, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Germany, and Europe, After Merkel
description: When Germans head to polls this weekend, they face an unusually difficult question: Who can replace Angela Merkel as a leader, for their country and for Europe?
content: After 16 years in power, Angela Merkel, the chancellor of Germany, is walking out of office one of the most popular politicians in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Pandemic Changes the World of Horse Auctions
description: Traditional speculators, known as pinhookers, are now vying with online buyers looking to invest in something new. The new bidders are driving up prices.
