content: Thoroughbred horses are always a bet on the future, whether you’re at the track and wagering on which one will win that day or an owner deciding which mares and sires will produce the best offspring — with no proof for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin, Apoorva Mandavilli and Benjamin Mueller
title: ‘Better to wait your turn in line,’ Biden says to those not yet eligible for Covid booster shots.
description: The authorization for boosters applies to groups of people in the United States fully vaccinated with the Pfizer vaccine, but about 45 percent of the country’s fully inoculated people received Moderna or Johnson & Johnson doses.
content: President Biden on Friday urged people who are not yet eligible for coronavirus booster shots to be patient, while suggesting eligibility could expand rapidly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Holding Back the Floodwaters
description: Homeowners who faced flooded basements after Hurricane Ida are pondering how to deal with the possibility of fiercer and more frequent storms.
content: How do you keep the water out when it seems unstoppable? That is the question that keeps Carrie Moore glued to her phone whenever it rains, scanning weather radar apps to try to determine whether the basement of her Sunset Park rowhouse will flood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Huawei, Booster Shots, Britney Spears: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: As a potential debt default looms, Yellen faces her biggest test yet.
description: When Janet L. Yellen was Federal Reserve chair in 2014, she faced a grilling from Republicans about whether the federal government had a plan if the nation’s borrowing limit was breached and measures to keep paying the country’s bills were exhausted.
content: When Janet L. Yellen was Federal Reserve chair in 2014, she faced a grilling from Republicans about whether the federal government had a plan if the nation’s borrowing limit was breached and measures to keep paying the country’s bills were exhausted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: Giving Love a Second Chance
description: Marissa Arnold and Joseph Deaux dated for a few months in 2014, but broke up to care for their mothers, both of whom were diagnosed with cancer. When they reconnected in 2017, they fell for each other again.
content: In September 2017, Joseph Ernest Glisson Deaux checked his phone during work and saw a text from a woman he had barely spoken to over the last few years, Marissa Beth Arnold. He and Ms. Arnold had met in April 2014 at a work event and dated for a few months, but before their relationship could get serious, Ms. Arnold’s mother was diagnosed with terminal cancer. Mr. Deaux’s mother also had late-stage cancer, and although they both had feelings for one another, they decided to stop seeing each other to focus on taking care of their families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: The U.S. could run out of cash to pay its bills as early as Oct. 15, analysts say.
description: The analysis showed a narrower window during which the United States could default on its debt. The Treasury has said it has no official contingency plan if the debt limit is breached.
content: The federal government could run out of cash and start missing payments on things as diverse as Social Security and military pay sometime between Oct. 15 and Nov. 4, according to a new analysis from the Bipartisan Policy Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Bozzone
title: Overlooked No More: Remedios Varo, Spanish Painter of Magic, Mysticism and Science
description: In the 1950s, and ’60s, she depicted women, artists and thinkers in intricate dreamlike canvases that now fetch high prices.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcel Theroux
title: From Anthony Doerr, an Ode to Storytelling That Shows How It’s Done
description: “Cloud Cuckoo Land,” Doerr’s first novel since “All the Light We Cannot See,” unites five characters over a millennium in a tribute to books and those who love them.
content: CLOUD CUCKOO LANDBy Anthony Doerr
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland, Reed Abelson and Jan Hoffman
title: States Begin a Complex Booster Shot Rollout for Pfizer Recipients
description: Health officials were preparing on Friday to start giving booster shots to older and at-risk Americans, trying to make sense of new and broad eligibility guidelines.
content: WASHINGTON — State health officials rushed on Friday to roll out campaigns to provide coronavirus booster shots for millions of vulnerable people who got the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine and to help a confused public understand who qualifies for the extra shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Two Covid vaccine pioneers win 2021 Lasker Awards in medicine.
content: Among this year’s recipients of the Lasker awards, announced Friday, were two scientists whose work was crucial in the development of Covid-19 vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: The U.S. has deported more than 2,000 Haitians, including some families, from a Texas camp with plans to deport more.
description: Another 3,900 Haitians are in government custody and will be deported or put into removal proceedings, according to federal officials.
content: The Biden administration has deported more than 2,000 Haitians since last week, a nearly even mix of single adults and families, out of the more than 12,000 that have been apprehended in a small Texas town by border officials, according to internal accounts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: A True Prizefight Follows a Summer of Sideshows
description: Anthony Joshua will try to defend his heavyweight titles on Saturday in a fight that could set up a bout against either Deontay Wilder or Tyson Fury.
content: Two days before he was scheduled to try to defend his heavyweight titles against the undefeated Oleksandr Usyk, Anthony Joshua sat at a news conference on Thursday in London, his hat, headphones and even water bottles positioned to make sponsor logos visible to the cameras.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Tracy Sherlock
title: Canadians weigh in on the Meng deal: ‘What about the two Michaels?’
description: While Meng Wanzhou contemplates flying to freedom to her home country, China, many Canadians on Friday lashed out at the continued imprisonment of two Canadians, known across the country as “the two Michaels.”
content: While Meng Wanzhou contemplates flying to freedom to her home country, China, many Canadians on Friday lashed out at the continued imprisonment of two Canadians, known across the country as “the two Michaels.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Randall Kennedy on ‘Say It Loud!’
description: Kennedy discusses his new essay collection, and Mary Roach talks about “Fuzz: When Nature Breaks the Law.”
content: The Harvard law professor Randall Kennedy’s new book, “Say It Loud!,” collects 29 of his essays. Kennedy’s opinions about the subjects listed in the book’s subtitle — race, law, history and culture — tend to be complex, and he’s not afraid to change his mind. He says on the podcast that there’s “no shame” in admitting you’re wrong, and that he does just that in the book when he finds it appropriate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: My Mission to Ferret Out a Lost Broadway Score
description: The music is a missing piece of the Fats Waller story.
content: It’s not hard to know that Fats Waller was a jazz pianist and entertainer who wrote great songs like “Ain’t Misbehavin’.” You can see him do what he did, in all facets, in the film “Stormy Weather” from 1943.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Hurricane Forecasters Aren’t Tweeting About Your Personal Life, They Swear
description: Kate was a “poorly organized depression.” The National Hurricane Center says it wasn’t personal.
content: “I can relate to that hurricane” is not a thought anyone wants to think.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: Stream an Operatic Rarity by a Black Composer (While You Can)
description: William Grant Still’s “Highway 1, U.S.A.,” staged by Opera Theater of St. Louis, is available online until Sept. 30.
content: Want a break from prestige TV for an evening? Good news: An important 20th-century American opera is newly available to stream, after a rare live staging this summer. And it’s about 50 minutes long, just like an episode of “The Crown.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Weeknight Chicken Recipe Has Mass Appeal
description: Delicate boneless, skinless thighs cook quickly, aren’t prone to drying out and pair beautifully with a garlicky cucumber yogurt.
content: Jack Sprat may eat no fat, but I wonder how he’d weigh in on boneless, skinless chicken thighs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Nailah Avery
title: In Oak Bluffs, Strangers Become Family
description: A first-time visitor to this Martha’s Vineyard town, long cherished by generations of Black travelers, finds that after a devastating year, warm welcomes, a strong sense of pride and the spirit of family remain constants.
content: Approaching Inkwell Beach on Martha’s Vineyard on a midsummer day, you feel a magnetic energy in the air. Before you can even see the ocean, familiar melodies waft through a set of speakers, everything from Beyoncé to Earth, Wind & Fire. Once on the small beach, steps from the main strip of Oak Bluffs, you are surrounded by Black beachgoers proudly wearing the insignia of Shaw University, Morgan State University and other historically Black colleges and universities. Members of the “Divine 9” — historically Black sororities and fraternities — glide about in their respective paraphernalia, and revelers of all ages socialize and take photos in the spirit of unfettered kinship. I feel and see Black joy everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: N.Y.C. schools prepare for staffing shortages as a vaccine mandate looms.
description: Thousands of Department of Education employees still haven’t received their first doses or haven’t submitted proof of vaccination.
content: The nation’s largest school system is preparing for disruption in some schools next week, as a vaccine mandate for virtually all adults working in New York City schools is set to take effect on Monday at midnight, which could result in staffing shortages by Tuesday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Michael Crowley and Rick Gladstone
title: Rebuking Biden, Iran’s Chief Diplomat Demands More Sanctions Relief
description: The foreign minister for Iran’s new hard-line government said it would demand a higher price for limiting its nuclear program than it did in the 2015 deal.
content: Accusing President Biden of continuing “the thick file of the Trump sanctions against Iran,’’ the new, hard-line Iranian foreign minister said on Friday that in return for agreeing to limits on its nuclear program, his country would demand far more sanctions relief than it received under the 2015 nuclear deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: To His Surprise, His Play About 2 Dead U.K. Politicians Struck a Chord
description: After decades in the political sphere, Michael McManus turned to theater. His play, “Maggie & Ted,” explores the tensions that would pave the way for Brexit.
content: LONDON — A play about two long-dead British politicians might not be an obvious winner in London’s West End. But this summer a brief run of “Maggie & Ted, the Birth of Brexit” attracted a sellout theater crowd, including a former prime minister, Theresa May, and its success seems to have surprised the playwright, Michael McManus, as much as anyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Arrest Warrant Issued for Brian Laundrie, Days After Gabrielle Petito’s Body Was Found
description: Mr. Laundrie is facing a felony charge of debit card fraud in Wyoming after the death of Ms. Petito, his fiancée, on a cross-country trip. The death has been ruled a homicide.
content: A federal arrest warrant was unsealed on Thursday in Wyoming for Brian Laundrie, the elusive fiancé of Gabrielle Petito, charging him with debit card fraud as the authorities continued to search for him as a “person of interest” in the investigation into the killing of Ms. Petito.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘The Devil You Know’ and ‘The Lying Life of Adults’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: MAGIC LESSONS, by Alice Hoffman. (Simon & Schuster, 416 pp., $17.) “Hoffman’s book swept me away during a time I most needed it,” our reviewer, Edan Lepucki, wrote of the third installment (and second prequel) in the Practical Magic fantasy series. While the plot here is darker than in the other novels, the storytelling, Lepucki enthused, is “(forgive me) bewitching.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass and Ricardo Labougle
title: In a Fading Portuguese Village, the Gardens Bloom Again
description: A landscape designer has transformed the town of Santar with a series of lush, connected plots where everyone is free to roam.
content: IN 2013, JOSE Luís Vasconcellos e Sousa, a now-62-year-old retired private bank executive living in Estoril, Portugal, cold-called the legendary Madrid-based landscape designer Fernando Caruncho with a proposal. Perhaps Caruncho, whose minimalist works evoke the monumental quality of 1970s land art, could create a contemporary extension to complement the 400-year-old formal garden of his ancestral estate in Santar, a village in Dão’s wine region, 90 minutes south of Porto.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Freeman Gill
title: Behind the Trees, a Brooklyn Artists’ Collective
description: A historic house in Clinton Hill South has been colonized by painters, designers, poets, architects and activists, living and working together.
content: Hidden by overgrown trees and flowering shrubs in need of a haircut, 70 Lefferts Place, in Brooklyn’s Clinton Hill, can be hard to find amid its neighboring rowhouses of brick and brownstone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
title: Hong Kong Is Holding Elections. It Wants Them to Look Real.
description: China has already determined the outcome, but the government is pressuring opposition parties to participate to lend the vote legitimacy.
content: HONG KONG — As far as the trappings of a healthy democracy go, Hong Kong’s upcoming legislative election has them all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: An Insider Details the ‘Black Box’ of Money and Power in China
description: A memoir by a well-connected businessman offers insights into the Communist Party’s thinking as it tightens its grip on the private sector.
content: To build a logistics hub next to Beijing’s main airport, Desmond Shum spent three years collecting 150 official seals from the many-layered Chinese bureaucracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Take an audio trip.
content: Welcome. You know those albums or songs that you so profoundly associate with a moment in your life that just the opening bars, maybe even just a couple of notes, function as a sort of time machine? You hear a song and you’re transported to that room in that house — maybe it’s your childhood bedroom, or your college dorm room. Maybe you’re 11 years old again, or you’re dating that person again, or you’re walking that very specific route to school again, the one on which you listened to this same album, over and over, on your Walkman (or Discman or iPod Nano).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Covid Vaccine Pioneers and Others Win 2021 Lasker Awards in Medicine
description: The prizes are given annually, and many winners often go on to be awarded the Nobel Prize.
content: The Lasker awards for 2021, announced Friday, were given to scientists whose work was crucial for Covid-19 vaccines, scientists who discovered how to control the firing of neurons with beams of light, and to a researcher whose influential work and leadership changed medical science.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: After a Few First ‘Dates’ the Relationship Turned Serious
description: Matthew Sipe and Ryan Watzel met in 2012 at Yale Law School and became fast friends.
content: On what they considered their first official date — a Halloween party in 2012 at a pub in New Haven, Conn. — Matthew Sipe and Ryan Watzel were in costume.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus J. Moore
title: A Music Obsession That’s Adventurous and Soothing
description: ‘The trick to crate digging is to simply go at it: Dive into the sections, flip through the jackets and trust your gut.’
content: I was stuck trying to write in my Brooklyn apartment, overthinking a sentence as usual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney Sues to Keep Complete Rights to Marvel Characters
description: The company filed several lawsuits seeking to invalidate copyright-termination notices served by artists and illustrators involved with creating superheroes like Spider-Man and Thor.
content: LOS ANGELES — Moving to defend its Marvel superhero franchises, the Walt Disney Company on Friday filed a flurry of lawsuits seeking to invalidate copyright-termination notices served by artists and illustrators involved with marquee characters like Iron Man, Spider-Man and Thor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Giulia Heyward
title: The woman who was killed is remembered as ‘kind, generous, caring, selfless.’
description: Olivia King died in a hospital after the gunman shot her in the chest, one of her sons said.
content: Olivia King was a regular parishioner at Catholic Church of the Incarnation in Collierville, Tenn., attending a service there on Thursday morning only hours before she was killed in a mass shooting at a Kroger grocery store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ray Mark Rinaldi
title: Paranormal Play in Denver From Meow Wolf
description: “Convergence Station,” the company’s third installation, may be good business. But is it good art?
content: DENVER —   Meow Wolf trades on the dark side of American popular culture, in cults and conspiracies, in supernatural beings, extraterrestrials and unsolvable conundrums. The chain of oversized, immersive art installations teases visitors who wander through its dimly-lit environments by dropping hints about nefarious mysteries they could spend a lifetime — not to mention multiple $45 admission charges — trying to work out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Alberta’s ‘Best Summer Ever’ Ends With an Overwhelmed Medical System
description: A surge of Covid-19 cases has forced the province to ask for military assistance in airlifting patients to hospitals across the country.
content: Premier Jason Kenney was roundly criticized by public health experts in June when he declared victory over the coronavirus and made Alberta the first province to largely lift pandemic restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: House Democrats say they plan action next week on the infrastructure bill and their social safety net plan.
description: An infrastructure vote had already been planned for Monday, and top Democrats said they also intended to take up their larger social policy and climate package.
content: House Democratic leaders on Friday said they would take up both a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill and a far-reaching, multitrillion-dollar social safety net plan next week, as they worked feverishly to bridge deep divisions within their ranks that are holding up President Biden’s top two domestic priorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Should We Bring Back Animals From Extinction?
description: A new company hopes to genetically resurrect the woolly mammoth thousands of years after it went extinct. Should these efforts be applauded or feared?
content: Have you ever seen the movie “Jurassic Park” or one of its sequels? It tells the story of an eccentric businessman who creates a theme park of cloned dinosaurs from prehistoric DNA, only to have his dreams ruined when the resurrected Tyrannosaurus rex and other ferocious predators escape and endanger the lives of the no-longer-thrilled human visitors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Former Louisiana Trooper Faces Federal Civil Rights Charge
description: Body-camera footage shows the ex-trooper, Jacob Brown, repeatedly pummeling a Black man, Aaron Larry Bowman, with a flashlight during a traffic stop in 2019.
content: A federal grand jury indicted a former Louisiana state trooper on Thursday on a federal civil rights violation, finding that he repeatedly clubbed a Black man with a flashlight during a traffic stop that was recorded by his body camera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
